description: Dan and Wes walk you through the step-by-steps to build a personal computer. They demonstrate the installation of components like a motherboard, CPU, cooling systems, fans hard drives and power supplies.
name: Building a PC
subtitle: Assembly and configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain some of the pre-planning required when preparing to build a custom PC. They then guide you through the process of shopping for components while sticking to the customer's budget.
episodes.title: Component Selection
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.909 --> 00:00:16.850
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:21.650
I'm your host Daniel Lowrey, joining me
today is none other than Mr. Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:21.650 --> 00:00:22.930
How's it going today Mr. Wes?.

5
00:00:22.930 --> 00:00:24.490
>> It's going great, it's good to be here.

6
00:00:24.490 --> 00:00:28.800
Good to be back with the ITProTV crew
here and, we got a really fun show today.

7
00:00:28.800 --> 00:00:31.280
We're gonna be talking
about building computers.

8
00:00:31.280 --> 00:00:34.480
And one of the things that we're gonna do
in this episode is we're gonna try to set

9
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:38.750
the stage for well what do you
need to put together, a list.

10
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:42.510
We're gonna develop our shopping list and
get our components ready to go.

11
00:00:42.510 --> 00:00:45.770
And we're gonna set a budget,
we're gonna find out.

12
00:00:45.770 --> 00:00:47.390
How close we can get to that budget.

13
00:00:47.390 --> 00:00:51.570
If we have a couple thousand dollars,
we have $5,000 out, well guess what?

14
00:00:51.570 --> 00:00:53.990
I don't really think we have a problem
>> [LAUGHS]

15
00:00:53.990 --> 00:00:55.650
>> on what we want to build.

16
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:57.470
But that's not always the case.

17
00:00:57.470 --> 00:01:00.450
Not everybody just has money to
just keep throwing out there.

18
00:01:00.450 --> 00:01:02.675
At least,
I don't know about you Dan I know I don't.

19
00:01:02.675 --> 00:01:04.040
[LAUGH]
>> I'm poor.

20
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:09.140
>> Right, so, hopefully one of the things
that we can do today is help you guys

21
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:14.270
when you come away from this show knowing
a little bit of the method to the madness.

22
00:01:14.270 --> 00:01:16.060
Developing a list, setting a budget, and

23
00:01:16.060 --> 00:01:19.960
seeing how close we can get to that budget
when it comes to building a computer.

24
00:01:19.960 --> 00:01:20.460
>> That's right.

25
00:01:20.460 --> 00:01:23.798
We're gonna kinda operate under
the assumption that we're a couple of

26
00:01:23.798 --> 00:01:26.411
computer techs, or
maybe you're a self employed guy,

27
00:01:26.411 --> 00:01:29.208
you're trying to get into the field and
do stuff like that.

28
00:01:29.208 --> 00:01:33.772
Building custom PCs for people is
typically a job that newbies get into and

29
00:01:33.772 --> 00:01:37.905
it's a great one, because it allows
you to work with components.

30
00:01:37.905 --> 00:01:41.269
You start understanding what's out there,
what's available for

31
00:01:41.269 --> 00:01:45.570
the customer market and working with
equipment, giving you some real hands on.

32
00:01:45.570 --> 00:01:48.580
So, that's one of the reasons
we wanted to do this show.

33
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:52.490
Now, as Wes said there's some
pre-planning that's gonna go along.

34
00:01:52.490 --> 00:01:55.100
We are gonna set a budget for ourselves,
it's not gonna be gargantuan.

35
00:01:55.100 --> 00:01:58.002
Win, but
it's not going to be a pittance either.

36
00:01:58.002 --> 00:02:00.870
We're gonna make sure that
it's mid to the road,

37
00:02:00.870 --> 00:02:02.910
make sure there's a little bit
of money in the kitty, for

38
00:02:02.910 --> 00:02:06.560
us to pick out some components,
and try to meet that mark.

39
00:02:06.560 --> 00:02:08.841
Now Wes, obviously we've got our budget.

40
00:02:08.841 --> 00:02:09.919
Where did we set our budget at?

41
00:02:09.919 --> 00:02:14.169
>> We set our budget
at around 700 to $800.

42
00:02:14.169 --> 00:02:17.465
At first Dan and I were talking, we're
like, we're going to go for $700, and

43
00:02:17.465 --> 00:02:18.325
then I was thinking.

44
00:02:18.325 --> 00:02:19.710
Well, we might need a little cushion.

45
00:02:19.710 --> 00:02:24.441
Because if I'm spending money, you always
have in your minds eye what you're

46
00:02:24.441 --> 00:02:27.462
gonna go for, but
sometimes it doesn't happen.

47
00:02:27.462 --> 00:02:31.770
So we're gonna say 700 to $800 range
here and we're gonna look at some of

48
00:02:31.770 --> 00:02:36.168
the components that we have to put into
that case, and some of the requirements.

49
00:02:36.168 --> 00:02:41.175
Now if you're the average end-user you
know you might save some money if you're

50
00:02:41.175 --> 00:02:46.048
just gonna buy it outright from an OEM,
or original equipment manufacturer.

51
00:02:46.048 --> 00:02:50.410
But one of the great things about building
your own and having it customized for you,

52
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:53.130
is you can tailor make it
a little more to your needs.

53
00:02:53.130 --> 00:02:54.600
So that's what we're gonna do here.

54
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:56.908
>> Awesome, so I guess, where do we begin?

55
00:02:56.908 --> 00:02:57.758
We've got our budget.

56
00:02:57.758 --> 00:02:58.860
>> That's right.

57
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:00.696
>> We know we don't need
the top of the line,

58
00:03:00.696 --> 00:03:03.017
we know we don't want
the bargain basement either.

59
00:03:03.017 --> 00:03:05.600
We need that mid range, so
now, where do we start?

60
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:07.218
What's the first component
we should tackle?

61
00:03:07.218 --> 00:03:07.921
>> That's right.

62
00:03:07.921 --> 00:03:11.740
Well, you need a place to store all the
components that are gonna be in the system

63
00:03:11.740 --> 00:03:13.116
unit, right, the system unit.

64
00:03:13.116 --> 00:03:16.341
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly, so with the system unit,

65
00:03:16.341 --> 00:03:18.740
it holds everything together, right?

66
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:21.530
Our system unit,
one of the major components

67
00:03:21.530 --> 00:03:25.080
that are part of the system unit is
something known as a case or a tower.

68
00:03:25.080 --> 00:03:28.070
You might hear many different terms,
chassis, case, tower.

69
00:03:28.070 --> 00:03:31.440
So, don't let any of
those terms confuse you.

70
00:03:31.440 --> 00:03:35.470
Just remember that some places might
call it a little bit different,

71
00:03:35.470 --> 00:03:37.979
primarily what we talk about is the tower.

72
00:03:37.979 --> 00:03:40.738
Now, when it comes to
the tower there are some very,

73
00:03:40.738 --> 00:03:43.318
very important things
that you got to consider.

74
00:03:43.318 --> 00:03:47.020
One of the first things we got to
consider is something called form factor.

75
00:03:47.020 --> 00:03:52.720
Now form factor for us typically
describes the size of the case and

76
00:03:52.720 --> 00:03:56.000
more importantly what kind of
motherboard we can put in the case.

77
00:03:56.000 --> 00:03:58.780
So thatâ€™s one of the first things
that you want to start out with.

78
00:03:58.780 --> 00:04:02.660
Now when it comes to the form factor,

79
00:04:02.660 --> 00:04:07.340
you can also have what is known as
the mid-range or the full tower.

80
00:04:07.340 --> 00:04:08.718
Now the full tower,
you've got to be careful.

81
00:04:08.718 --> 00:04:10.553
It might be the size of
a small refrigerator.

82
00:04:10.553 --> 00:04:14.470
So if you're storing your components,
how big is your desk?

83
00:04:14.470 --> 00:04:17.160
You really have to consider:
do I have a lot of space?

84
00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:20.740
If I have a lot of space, well then, I
could probably go with a full size tower.

85
00:04:21.790 --> 00:04:23.230
Maybe space is a little bit limited,

86
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:28.070
and if it is you can reduce that
down to even a midsize tower.

87
00:04:28.070 --> 00:04:31.010
Maybe you don't have any space at all and

88
00:04:31.010 --> 00:04:35.230
then you're going to go even smaller form
factor of what's known as a slimline case.

89
00:04:35.230 --> 00:04:37.952
But we're gonna go ahead and
hit middle of the road here.

90
00:04:37.952 --> 00:04:41.950
We're gonna say we're not going to go for
the refrigerator size computer and

91
00:04:41.950 --> 00:04:44.780
at the same time we're not gonna go for
the matchbox size computer.

92
00:04:44.780 --> 00:04:49.640
I think one of the best mid range form
factors is gonna be something known

93
00:04:49.640 --> 00:04:52.550
as your midsize ATXK.

94
00:04:52.550 --> 00:04:55.080
So it's one that's very important for us.

95
00:04:55.080 --> 00:04:59.250
Now when you're considering buying a case

96
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:01.570
there are some characteristics
that you have to be aware of.

97
00:05:01.570 --> 00:05:05.580
For instance how many hard
drives can you store in this.

98
00:05:05.580 --> 00:05:09.306
Now again we're not gonna go with a gaming
case where we have to have a gazillion

99
00:05:09.306 --> 00:05:10.955
drives, and that'd be awesome.

100
00:05:10.955 --> 00:05:14.090
But you also gotta think
about things like expansion.

101
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:17.698
So if I start out with a case that
only has maybe two hard drive bays,

102
00:05:17.698 --> 00:05:21.510
well I'm kinda limited as to what I
can do potentially in the future.

103
00:05:21.510 --> 00:05:26.530
So we have to make sure that we get
a case that has enough drive bays for it.

104
00:05:26.530 --> 00:05:29.300
We need to make sure that what kinda

105
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:31.770
optical drives we might need
to put into this machine.

106
00:05:31.770 --> 00:05:34.989
Are we gonna have one that's DVD,
maybe one that's Blu-ray.

107
00:05:34.989 --> 00:05:36.361
Are we gonna have a combo?

108
00:05:36.361 --> 00:05:40.629
Because that's the difference between
having enough of the five and a half inch

109
00:05:40.629 --> 00:05:45.180
bays that optical drives typically
stay in, versus not having enough.

110
00:05:45.180 --> 00:05:47.710
So some good considerations there.

111
00:05:47.710 --> 00:05:52.330
One of the things you also have to
consider too, if you're gonna buy a case.

112
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:57.140
Do I need any front panel connectors,
in the positioning of those connectors?

113
00:05:57.140 --> 00:06:00.220
Some people, they put their case right
next to them where their work station is,

114
00:06:00.220 --> 00:06:03.270
and they like top mounted IO ports.

115
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:07.840
Maybe to be able to plug in a headset
to the top of the case rather than

116
00:06:07.840 --> 00:06:10.630
having to fumble down and
plug it down into the bottom of the case.

117
00:06:10.630 --> 00:06:14.280
So that might really be something
you have to consider as well.

118
00:06:14.280 --> 00:06:17.400
Sometimes you can even get them
with ESATA ports on the top.

119
00:06:17.400 --> 00:06:20.450
If I've got an extra laptop drive
that I'm not using anymore,

120
00:06:20.450 --> 00:06:21.740
I can just plug it right in.

121
00:06:21.740 --> 00:06:24.010
And I can use it as an external drive.

122
00:06:24.010 --> 00:06:29.020
I would say probably one thing that you
also have to consider is power supplies.

123
00:06:29.020 --> 00:06:32.470
Is the power supply gonna
be part of the case or not.

124
00:06:32.470 --> 00:06:35.960
So, one of the things that we're going
to do here is, let's go ahead and

125
00:06:35.960 --> 00:06:39.470
maybe take a look at some cases,
maybe do some comparison here.

126
00:06:39.470 --> 00:06:44.095
So, we've gone and kinda done some
of the research ahead of time.

127
00:06:44.095 --> 00:06:51.175
To try to help just ease the burden of all
of the research you have to do for this.

128
00:06:51.175 --> 00:06:53.355
So let's go ahead and

129
00:06:53.355 --> 00:06:56.955
I've got our computer case
pulled up here on the screen.

130
00:06:56.955 --> 00:07:01.420
Now, one of the things that you
want to do, do your research.

131
00:07:01.420 --> 00:07:04.190
You can go to many different places here.

132
00:07:04.190 --> 00:07:07.980
I've got one pulled up, again kind
of doing that research beforehand.

133
00:07:07.980 --> 00:07:09.210
I've also got one here.

134
00:07:09.210 --> 00:07:10.030
Tiger direct too.

135
00:07:10.030 --> 00:07:14.660
So you do have a couple of options, but
one of the first things you want to do

136
00:07:14.660 --> 00:07:16.772
is you want to look at
the specifications of the case.

137
00:07:16.772 --> 00:07:19.110
>> Good idea.
When it comes to cases like we've been

138
00:07:19.110 --> 00:07:20.440
kinda hinting toward.

139
00:07:20.440 --> 00:07:23.340
You need enough room inside
to put all your components if

140
00:07:23.340 --> 00:07:28.270
you're gonna have some massive gaming
rig that's super awesome, gigantic,

141
00:07:28.270 --> 00:07:31.500
crazy video cards that you can buy and
I've seen them there.

142
00:07:31.500 --> 00:07:33.840
They have their own fans and
heatsinks and everything.

143
00:07:33.840 --> 00:07:35.120
You're going to need room for that, right?

144
00:07:35.120 --> 00:07:39.686
So buying the correct case for what your
application is, is kind of important.

145
00:07:39.686 --> 00:07:43.172
Now Wes you talked a little bit at the
beginning when we were jumping into this

146
00:07:43.172 --> 00:07:43.946
case business.

147
00:07:43.946 --> 00:07:45.485
>> Mm-hm.
>> About form factors.

148
00:07:45.485 --> 00:07:47.115
Different types of motherboards as well.

149
00:07:47.115 --> 00:07:48.215
>> Yep.
>> Also has to make sure

150
00:07:48.215 --> 00:07:49.595
it fits the right motherboard, right?

151
00:07:49.595 --> 00:07:50.565
>> That's, that's right too.

152
00:07:50.565 --> 00:07:54.084
So, for instance, the case that I have
right here, the one that I've picked out.

153
00:07:54.084 --> 00:07:56.793
And I've got a couple, so
I'm not just picking on one vendor.

154
00:07:56.793 --> 00:07:58.126
You might have a vendor
out there you like.

155
00:07:58.126 --> 00:07:59.169
This is New Egg, great vendor.

156
00:07:59.169 --> 00:08:00.876
We got another one here.

157
00:08:00.876 --> 00:08:02.626
For TigerDirect.

158
00:08:02.626 --> 00:08:07.716
Now notice they've got some of
the same specifications and

159
00:08:07.716 --> 00:08:15.090
the specification I want you to look at
here is Standard ATX, microATX, Mini-ITX.

160
00:08:15.090 --> 00:08:17.250
If I switch on over to the other
one that we've looked at,

161
00:08:17.250 --> 00:08:21.030
well, they've only got one ATX,
but what does that mean for us?

162
00:08:21.030 --> 00:08:25.060
Well, the ATX form factor has
differed throughout the years.

163
00:08:25.060 --> 00:08:30.520
So you have to be very very mindful of
what motherboard form factor you're gonna

164
00:08:30.520 --> 00:08:35.330
get, because three of the form factors
that have to match in any computer build.

165
00:08:35.330 --> 00:08:36.470
We've already mentioned one.

166
00:08:36.470 --> 00:08:40.360
The case is very important cuz
everything has to fit inside the case.

167
00:08:40.360 --> 00:08:44.320
But then the second factor that's
coming up here is the motherboard.

168
00:08:44.320 --> 00:08:47.290
The case and the motherboard have to
match, because if you get one of these

169
00:08:48.320 --> 00:08:51.720
giant motherboards and you try to put
it into this little top set like box,

170
00:08:51.720 --> 00:08:53.730
well, obviously,
you're not gonna break out the hammer and

171
00:08:53.730 --> 00:08:56.800
try to break that thing in there and
do any customizations.

172
00:08:56.800 --> 00:09:01.000
So, I have to make sure that
if I've got a ATX case,

173
00:09:01.000 --> 00:09:03.640
in this case you can see some
of the specifications behind it.

174
00:09:03.640 --> 00:09:05.400
Does it have what I need?

175
00:09:05.400 --> 00:09:09.290
Well, it's got three, oh,
five and a quarter inch base.

176
00:09:09.290 --> 00:09:11.180
It looks like this one has, what is it?

177
00:09:11.180 --> 00:09:13.510
Three and a half inch base,
which are internal drives.

178
00:09:13.510 --> 00:09:15.810
And this one even
supports solid state too.

179
00:09:15.810 --> 00:09:19.120
So you can see those 2.5 inch drive bays.

180
00:09:19.120 --> 00:09:22.560
Now, I have to get a motherboard
that matches the same thing.

181
00:09:22.560 --> 00:09:23.545
I've gone ahead and

182
00:09:23.545 --> 00:09:28.640
I've picked a motherboard that you can
see has the Micro ATX form factor.

183
00:09:28.640 --> 00:09:31.270
Now here's the thing
that I have to consider,

184
00:09:31.270 --> 00:09:34.580
is the Micro ATX gonna fit in this case?

185
00:09:34.580 --> 00:09:36.860
Well if we went with this case,

186
00:09:36.860 --> 00:09:40.560
we might run into a problem cuz
remember it only says ATX here.

187
00:09:40.560 --> 00:09:44.690
So if I scroll down and I wanna find out,
does this motherboard have

188
00:09:44.690 --> 00:09:49.740
the compatibility with my case or
vice versa, however you wanna say that.

189
00:09:49.740 --> 00:09:52.020
One of the first things I have to
do is I have to look right here and

190
00:09:52.020 --> 00:09:54.330
you can see this says MICRO ATX.

191
00:09:54.330 --> 00:09:55.400
And ATX here.

192
00:09:55.400 --> 00:10:01.240
So looks like this motherboard is going
to support our case, or vice versa.

193
00:10:01.240 --> 00:10:02.960
Our case is going to
support our motherboard.

194
00:10:04.130 --> 00:10:09.550
Now, when it comes to your motherboard,
the form factor is absolutely critical.

195
00:10:09.550 --> 00:10:14.720
Now, in relationship to your case, a lot
of times when you see these multiple form

196
00:10:14.720 --> 00:10:18.750
factor names in the list, it's because
they have different mounting points.

197
00:10:18.750 --> 00:10:23.549
So you don't have to worry about, it's
not certainly a one size fits all, but

198
00:10:23.549 --> 00:10:26.620
you can fit different form
factors inside there.

199
00:10:26.620 --> 00:10:30.923
The other thing I think about when I think
about a motherboard is going to be how

200
00:10:30.923 --> 00:10:33.320
many hard drive connections does it have?

201
00:10:33.320 --> 00:10:36.460
Does it have video support?

202
00:10:36.460 --> 00:10:37.910
Does it have sound support?

203
00:10:37.910 --> 00:10:42.828
But I can tell you one of the first things
that we really need to know here is this

204
00:10:42.828 --> 00:10:47.460
whole concept of what family,
what product line are we going to go with?

205
00:10:47.460 --> 00:10:51.640
And for us today there's really
two major product lines.

206
00:10:51.640 --> 00:10:55.640
And that product line is either going
to be Intel or it's going to be AMD.

207
00:10:55.640 --> 00:10:58.080
Now, when it comes to that,
that's going to be your choice.

208
00:10:58.080 --> 00:11:01.510
Some people like Intel and
are going to stick with Intel.

209
00:11:01.510 --> 00:11:04.510
Some people like AMD and
they're gonna stick with AMD.

210
00:11:04.510 --> 00:11:08.760
And that is one of the most crucial
things, I would say if you're gonna start

211
00:11:08.760 --> 00:11:13.610
with a motherboard, you have to know
well what product line am I gonna get,

212
00:11:13.610 --> 00:11:17.610
because in some of the other components
that we talk about they have to match.

213
00:11:17.610 --> 00:11:18.860
You can't mix and match.

214
00:11:18.860 --> 00:11:23.690
So knowing whether you're going to go with
AMD or you're going to go with Intel,

215
00:11:23.690 --> 00:11:26.680
is going to be one of the first
things that you want to discuss.

216
00:11:26.680 --> 00:11:27.913
>> Yeah.
And then don't forget,

217
00:11:27.913 --> 00:11:29.490
you got to cool the stinking things.

218
00:11:29.490 --> 00:11:32.920
Whether you're an AMD fan or
you're an Intel fan, great.

219
00:11:32.920 --> 00:11:34.905
Wave that flag as hard as you like.

220

444
00:22:45.380 --> 00:22:48.380
get lots of storage, that's gonna
not cost you as much as solid state.

445
00:22:48.380 --> 00:22:51.800
But if you still want to go solid
state cuz you just, like he said,

446
00:22:51.800 --> 00:22:55.240
maybe you're running Photoshop,
maybe you're doing audio work or

447
00:22:55.240 --> 00:22:57.150
video rendering, those types of things.

448
00:22:57.150 --> 00:22:59.870
This application can really hit
performance when it comes to

449
00:22:59.870 --> 00:23:00.620
the drive itself.

450
00:23:00.620 --> 00:23:05.030
So, go with a small SSD for
things like the applications and

451
00:23:05.030 --> 00:23:09.090
the operating system and then spend
the rest of your money as much storage

452
00:23:09.090 --> 00:23:11.140
with a mechanical drives as you can.

453
00:23:11.140 --> 00:23:12.980
Probably, the best of both worlds, right.

454
00:23:12.980 --> 00:23:15.720
>> Yeah,
I've got an older Intel X 25 M and

455
00:23:15.720 --> 00:23:17.990
it's just a little 80
gig solid state drive.

456
00:23:17.990 --> 00:23:19.900
And I put my operating system on that.

457
00:23:19.900 --> 00:23:23.450
I ended up going out and
getting a second 80 gig solid state drive,

458
00:23:23.450 --> 00:23:25.210
you're saying 80 gigs, man.

459
00:23:25.210 --> 00:23:26.970
Gosh, I got thumb drives that
are bigger than that today.

460
00:23:26.970 --> 00:23:28.420
What are you using it for?

461
00:23:28.420 --> 00:23:31.440
I don't put any data on it,
other than what applications need.

462
00:23:31.440 --> 00:23:33.540
So, for instance,
I use virtualization technology,

463
00:23:33.540 --> 00:23:37.870
so I put all of my virtual machines
on that second stylus state drive.

464
00:23:37.870 --> 00:23:43.100
But when it comes to the data like my,
I don't know videos,

465
00:23:43.100 --> 00:23:46.450
my music, that data,
I don't really access too much.

466
00:23:46.450 --> 00:23:49.420
And it can stand on,
it can sit on those traditional drives.

467
00:23:49.420 --> 00:23:52.050
And the one good thing about
the traditional drives is if you're just

468
00:23:52.050 --> 00:23:55.610
storing your data, you can scale
up to a very large capacity for

469
00:23:55.610 --> 00:23:57.180
a relatively cheap amount today.

470
00:23:57.180 --> 00:24:01.750
You're drives, like, Western Digital
Caviar Black editions which is

471
00:24:01.750 --> 00:24:07.120
a higher end PC hard drive,
they go for 70 bucks.

472
00:24:07.120 --> 00:24:10.730
So very easily,
you could go up to two to four terabytes.

473
00:24:10.730 --> 00:24:13.690
It doesn't cost quite as
much as the solid state.

474
00:24:13.690 --> 00:24:16.410
But again,
if you need the performance solid states,

475
00:24:16.410 --> 00:24:17.580
it is going to be where it's at.

476
00:24:17.580 --> 00:24:18.500
>> All right.
So what are we going

477
00:24:18.500 --> 00:24:20.900
to put inside of our computer
that we're building today?

478
00:24:20.900 --> 00:24:24.500
>> We're gonna go ahead,
we're gonna put a, let's see here.

479
00:24:24.500 --> 00:24:29.760
We've got a case here,
this is the series 200 R Corsair.

480
00:24:29.760 --> 00:24:37.180
I think what we're gonna see here,
is this LGA Intel gigabyte board.

481
00:24:37.180 --> 00:24:43.700
We kind of went mid range on the processor
here cuz everybody wants the i7.

482
00:24:43.700 --> 00:24:50.370
But we said, not quite the i7,
we're gonna go with the i5 here.

483
00:24:50.370 --> 00:24:53.030
All right, here's the one that I think
is going to be best for our build.

484
00:24:53.030 --> 00:24:55.070
It's a drive that I've actually used.

485
00:24:55.070 --> 00:24:59.729
And this one here is the western
digital black series, so you're gonna

486
00:24:59.729 --> 00:25:04.340
get moderate amount of performance out of
this, it's got the larger cache in it and

487
00:25:04.340 --> 00:25:07.890
you know the price isn't too bad either,
it's only about $70.

488
00:25:07.890 --> 00:25:11.270
So, you know dollar for dollar,
one terabyte drive here,

489
00:25:11.270 --> 00:25:15.630
7200 RPM's on the newest interface for
$70.

490
00:25:15.630 --> 00:25:19.210
You really can't beat that, especially
if you're again, building for a budget.

491
00:25:19.210 --> 00:25:19.780
>> Awesome.

492
00:25:19.780 --> 00:25:20.350
>> Yep.

493
00:25:20.350 --> 00:25:23.740
>> All right, Wes, well, really good
looking drive you got there and

494
00:25:23.740 --> 00:25:26.720
that's gonna be great for
our build what we're trying to do.

495
00:25:26.720 --> 00:25:29.100
And you know what, we've got a whole
lot more that we gotta talk about.

496
00:25:29.100 --> 00:25:32.230
There's actually a few more components
we wanna stick in this turkey but

497
00:25:32.230 --> 00:25:34.110
we've run out of time for this episode.

498
00:25:34.110 --> 00:25:36.020
So we're gonna have to make a part two.

499
00:25:36.020 --> 00:25:37.770
Wes, I know I'm looking forward to it.

500
00:25:37.770 --> 00:25:39.710
I can't wait to see what the end price is.

501
00:25:39.710 --> 00:25:41.100
Did we meet our budget or not?

502
00:25:41.100 --> 00:25:41.870
>> We're hoping [LAUGH].

503
00:25:41.870 --> 00:25:43.560
>> Yeah, we are hoping at that.

504
00:25:43.560 --> 00:25:45.500
Hopefully, we'll see you
guys in part two on that.

505
00:25:45.500 --> 00:25:47.400
But as for this,
we're gonna go ahead and close it down.

506
00:25:47.400 --> 00:25:50.370
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Danielle Lawrie.

507
00:25:50.370 --> 00:25:51.300
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

508
00:25:51.300 --> 00:25:59.520
>> And we'll see you next time
>> [SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes finish up shopping for their custom PC build. They pick up where they left off choosing components like optical drives, video cards, sound cards, and RAM.
episodes.title: Component Selection Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel walk you through assembling a PC from its individual components all the way to a functioning powered up state. They start with mounting the motherboard to the case and from there go though installing the CPU, RAM, liquid cooling system, hard drive, and power supply.
episodes.title: PC Assembly

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes help you to understand and configure the Basic Input/Output System(BIOS) of a computer. Here they explain many of the sections like memory speed, cpu cores, and Hyper-Threading, then move into the importance of the system date/time. They also show you how to configure on board devices and determine hard drive detection.
episodes.title: BIOS Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel continue describing BIOS features. Here they cover topics like performance, which entails cpu speed, memory speed, and overclocking. Also they take a look at some BIOS security and power features. Finally they show you how to adjust the boot features of the system.
episodes.title: BIOS Configuration Part 2
